text: Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1), the causative agent of AIDS, encodes three essential structural polyproteins (Gag, Pol and Env), two regulatory proteins (Tat and Rev), and four accessory proteins (Vif, Vpr, Vpu and Nef) 1 . The vpu gene is present in HIV-1 and certain simian immunodeficiency viruses (SIVs; SIVgsn, SIVmus, SIVmon) but not in HIV-2 or other SIVs. Vpu is a 16-kDa, type I integral membrane phosphoprotein that is expressed from a bicistronic mRNA together with the Env glycoprotein 2 . Vpu contains an amino-terminal transmembrane (TM) domain and a carboxy-terminal cytoplasmic tail (CT). The CT of Vpu consists of two α -helices linked by a short loop. Two serine residues (S52 and S56) that undergo phosphorylation to recruit β -TrCP, a key component of the SkpI-Cullin-F-box E3 ubiquitin ligase complex, are located in the short loop 3 . Vpu is primarily localized in the ER and Golgi and also to some extent at the plasma membrane 4 .
